Award.AwardTitle: Coupled metamaterial resonators for real-time tunable electromagnetic materials

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
The objective of this research is to develop tunable terahertz metamaterials to create a new class of compact electromagnetic devices for rapid real-time sensing and detection. This will be accomplished though integration of micro-capacitive actuators with broadside coupled split ring resonators enabling mechanical tuning of the interlayer coupling and associated electromagnetic response.

The intellectual merit of this research is that it provides a novel approach to realize active and dynamic metamaterials. Strongly coupled metamaterial resonators provide a unique and, as yet unrealized, route to create tunable and adaptive electromagnetic composites. The transformative aspect of this project is the implementation of lateral displacement of coupled resonators using microelectromechanical systems technology. Fundamental interactions between split ring resonators in the strong coupling limit will be investigated as a function of lateral and interlayer spacing. This will enable optimization of the precision voltage-controlled response such that new metamaterial designs and fabrication methodologies can be used to implement real-time frequency tuning from terahertz to mid-infrared wavelengths. The chemical sensing capability of such metamaterials will be investigated given theoretical indications of enhanced sensitivity and selectivity afforded by the mechanically tuning.

The broader impact of this research includes interdisciplinary education and training of undergraduate and graduate students, fostering development at the boundaries of research disciplines where exciting scientific and technological advances occur. Further, this project will serve as an excellent vehicle to recruit and women and minority scientists, and lead to the development of contemporary courses spanning from biology to physics, photonics, and engineering.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project aims to develop coupled metamaterial resonators for constructing dynamically tunable electromagnetic materials towards chemical sensing applications. With the help of modern electromagnetic theory, this project aims to investigate and create electromagnetic metamaterials that exploit the large effects associated with a coupled-to-decoupled crossover transition in metamaterials. Most of the conventional electromagnetic metamaterials are with static response, which limits their applications in some important scenarios, such as chemical sensing, imaging and light modulation. By integrating microelectromechanical systems (MEMS) actuators with the metamaterial concept, we aim to develop a set of real-time tunable metamaterials with large dynamic range for terahertz (THz) chemical sensing applications.

This work highlights the marriage between engineer and physics to develop novel functional devices, as well as break the limitations in traditional material design. In this project, we investigated the near field interactions between a variety of coupled resonators, such as broadside coupled split ring resonators, to enrich our understanding regarding metamaterials and plasmonics. Different from single layer metamaterials, the coupling factor in the strongly coupled resonators provide us an efficient way to control the properties of the metamaterials, such as effective refraction index, attenuation coefficient, anisotropic response, and local field distribution. This extra tunability enables a wide range of novel applications.

We developed micromachining processes to implement the real-time tunable metamaterials. The development of the metamaterials advances some key processes, including low stress film coating, deep silicon etching, critical point releasing, and flip chip bonding, for MEMS and semiconductor industries. The customized high precision fabrication process allowed us to control the separation distance and lateral shift between the coupled resonators. It can be considered as a paradigm to construct MEMS sensors and actuators, which may be adopted in building functional devices for applications ranging from physical sensors to biomedical detectors.

In addition, the terahertz technology is advanced by the development of the functional metamaterial devices. The THz time domain spectroscopy (TDS) was improved with increased sampling rate in order to capture the dynamic response of the metamaterial. The developed MEMS metamaterials provided a high degree of modulation in the amplitude, phase and polarization of THz radiation. As a result, the functional metamaterial devices operated as dynamic THz filter, equalizer, and polarizer to modulate the amplitude, group delay, and chirality of THz waves in a real-time fashion. By modulating the resonance frequency of the metamaterial, we probed the chemical properties in the environment by monitoring the interaction between metamaterial unit cells and chemical molecules. Such active control of metamaterial properties was considered to be useful for developing imaging and sensing THz technologies.

The project provides a unique educational environment for the graduate and undergraduate students involved in this project. This work, a close collaboration between the engineering and physics disciplines inherently necessitates the close collaboration of graduate students. Their unique and distinct backgrounds afford the students a unique opportunity to develop the skill sets requisite to collaborating in such a highly interdisciplinary setting, training the next generation of scientists to cross traditional disciplinary boundaries. The results of the project have been disseminated to a wider audience through participation in several national and international conferences and the publication of papers in high-impact journals, some of which were also selected as the cover images or featured by Science. Honors/awards have also been received during the course of the project, including Inventor of the Year Award and the Charles DeLisi Award at Boston University.

In addition to the impact on the microsystems research community, this project offered abundant opportunities for education given its multidisciplinary nature which integrates physics, material science, and engineering. In addition to employing the efforts of undergraduate students each year, this research supported graduate students towards doctoral degree, serving to develop the next generation of highly interdisciplinary scientists and fostering development at the boundaries of research disciplines where exciting scientific and technological advances occur. Multiple undergraduate students including female and underrepresented groups participated the project and gained knowledge, experience, and inspiration through the design, fabrication and testing of the microsystems and photonics devices. Teachers from public schools, especially those from the schools that work with the Massachusetts STEM Pipeline Networks and schools with high percentages of underrepresented minorities were also included in the project, resulting in healthy communication and inspirations among the teachers.
